summary: This document is a chain of email correspondence from July 2019, primarily containing a standard government travel policy reminder, followed by a series of embedded email threads from March to July 2019. These threads show FBI agents and an Assistant U.S. Attorney repeatedly requesting and receiving approval for travel to Florida (Palm Beach, West Palm Beach, Fort Lauderdale) and Los Angeles to conduct victim interviews and meetings related to the Epstein investigation (case 2018R01618, United States v. Epstein). The emails reveal the ongoing investigative activity months before Epstein's arrest.

persons.name: A. Strauch
persons.context: Identified as an Assistant U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York who, along with an FBI agent, requests travel permission for the Epstein investigation in March 2019.

connections.description: Work together as part of the investigative/prosecutorial team traveling for victim interviews in the Epstein case.

events.title: Planned Travel for Victim Interviews
events.description: FBI agents plan to travel to Palm Beach, Florida, for victim interviews, starting the day after this email (July 10) through Sunday.

events.title: Travel for LA Victim Interview
events.description: The investigative team requested and received approval to travel to Los Angeles the following week for a victim interview.

events.title: Travel for Florida Meetings
events.description: The team requested approval to travel to West Palm Beach, Florida, for approximately three days for meetings and victim interviews.

events.title: Travel for Florida Interviews
events.description: An FBI agent and A. Strauch requested approval to travel to West Palm Beach, Florida, for meetings and interviews related to United States v. Epstein.

events.title: Initial Travel Request for Investigation
events.description: A. Strauch and an FBI agent requested permission to travel to West Palm Beach/Fort Lauderdale, Florida, for two days of meetings and interviews for the Epstein investigation.

keyFacts: The document shows active FBI and DOJ investigation into Jeffrey Epstein (case 2018R01618, United States v. Epstein) for enticement of minors from at least March to July 2019.
Investigators were traveling to Florida and California specifically to conduct victim interviews, indicating witness coordination was a key part of the probe.
The emails reference a consistent need to reserve hotel conference rooms for conducting interviews during travel.
The correspondence is bureaucratic, showing standard government travel approval processes being used for a high-profile sex crimes investigation.
The investigation was ongoing for months prior to Epstein's arrest in July 2019.
